The Government researcher who directed the production of a controversial report on acid rain has resigned for what he said were personal reasons.

The official, Laurence Kulp, said he would step down Oct. 3 from his post as research director of the National Acid Precipitation Assessment Program, the interagency group that has spent more than $300 million since 1980 in an effort to learn more about acid rain.

The program's interim report, issued Sept. 17, concluded there was no evidence that a significant number of Northeastern lakes would get much more acidic under current levels of acid rain, but lakes in the Southeast could continue to worsen.

Environmentalists assert that acid rain is acidifying lakes in the Northeast to the point that fish are killed. Several groups attacked the interim report summary as a distortion of the scientific reports on which it was based.
